ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Philosophy of political theory
How to read long passages of reading
I think I gained an important foundational understanding of political philosophy which will help me going forward with the major!

I learned much about the ways in which the political systems of the modern day world were influenced by and transformed from the ancient, classical, renaissance, and enlightenment philosophical writings of politicians and philosophers.
How to apply political theories to current issues
I learned about a lot of different philosophies related to political science.
Lots of focus on the critiques of authors in our writing, and how to write cohesively.
Learned a great deal about applying ancient philosophical ideas to modern political phenomena.
Better understanding of political philosophy
I was exposed to theories by Plato to Gandhi about how politics should operate.
I learned how to write a philosophy paper according to basic fundamentals.
Introductory political philosophy skills.

I was able to understand higher-level text more thoroughly. The class really challenged me to find the deeper meaning of philosophical text, especially when it came to finding a meaning that wasn't as mainstream.
A broader understanding of philosophy from a Black perspective! I feel like there are limited philosophy courses that explore ethics from a Black perspective so I really appreciated this
I was able to learn how to write a philosophy paper.
I learned the basics about political philosophy and well-known political philosophers.

I learned how to breakdown/analyze philosophical arguments, how to interpret them, and how to evaluate them. I also learned how to synthesize and outline my evaluations and interpretations through writing. Some good insights about where humans think power is derived, how we ought to organize society and how we ought to alter the way we organize society

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very good no weaknesses
This course was extremely mundane for me. I felt as though the professor interacted with students very minimally. Her style of teaching was purely presentations that were hard to understand.

The lectures are very engaging if you are interested in the material! For those who are less interested, it might help their focus to have smaller group discussions instead of full group discussions during lecture (turn and talk to the person next to you and then share out, etc).

Discussion section does a very good job distilling knowledge and allowing for a stronger connection to the material; the lecture atmosphere is sometimes hard to follow with the sheer volume of information that is presented.

Strengths: Lots of interesting concepts.
Weaknesses: There was way too much reading for this class. Often, Professor Oskian would go over all of it in class to, so it was useless to actually do it myself. I felt like it was just being regurgitated to me. I think there should be fewer readings and philosophers so that we can actually understand each better rather than moving on so quickly. We also never get our papers back, which makes it hard to improve.
Having guest lecturersspeak about the practical application of the concepts; I.e., how the concepts show up in politics
Lectures were difficult to follow, but the readings and content were interesting. The syllabus was organized logically and there was a lot of comparison between philosophers.

The strengths are the lectures, which are incredibly digestible and super helpful to learning the content of the theory without having to bend over backwards to interpret it, and the discussion sections, which I thoroughly enjoyed. The weaknesses are the lack of instruction as to how to properly write a philosophy paper for those who have never written one before.
It was really good.

The strength would be that it exposed me to a wide range of political philosophy, but the reading could sometimes be a little overwhelming. I think it would have been better to assign less hefty reading blocks because I found myself getting lost and distracted at times. This would also help to make the class more effective and engaging.
Strengths are in its TAs who offered amazing support but the in class experience was very boring and monotonous.
Directions in some assignments were unclear with lack of teaching.

Strengths: Slides were helpful to know what the readings were saying 
Weaknesses: Sometimes I didn't understand what the professor was saying in class
The course was honestly boring. It was bearable, but I never felt excited to go to class.

Strengths: very resourceful and insightful prof. her lecture slides are very detailed, she provides them all, along with the readings, and her interpretations of the quotes, arguments, etc. during class are really helpful in aiding your personal understanding of what the thinker is trying to get across. Great TA, I thought he encouraged our thinking and helped lead us to salient points well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The content was interesting, but learning from this professor was difficult. She has a very faint voice.
I would if you are really interested in political philosophy. This course will be very helpful to you moving forward with the major.
I would really only recommend it if its required or if you love philosophy. If there were fewer readings, I would also recommend it if you wanted an intro to political philosophical thoughts.
Yes. I enjoyed this course, and the workload was very manageable.
Yes
Yes, to any student who wants to establish a foundational understanding of the concepts

I would recommend this course to someone who enjoys deep philosophical discussions and someone comfortable with difficult vernacular. The content is interesting, but I found it hard to follow Professor Oskian as she talks eloquently.
Yes, I would because it gave me a strong foundation for political theory, and it challenged me to write in a fashion I never have before.
Yes.
I feel like I would definitely recommend the class, especially if the recommendations I made were considered.

This course probably doesnt quite deserve its reputation. It does provide a very effective and comprehensive overview of political philosophy. No, Prof. Oskian isnt the most engaging lecturer, but shes a good professor otherwise. I do hope that shell reflect on why shes had to make attendance mandatory, perhaps using very engaging philosophy professors like Shelly Kagan (who doesnt have an attendance problem) as a reference point. The readings were doable, although they werent distributed entirely evenly, so the weekly reading volume was, at times, hard to predict. The essay topics were interesting and fun to engage with. The grading was reasonable, although it took unacceptably long for our graded papers to be released to us (so much so that I couldnt account for my second-paper feedback while writing my third paper). Generally, I wouldnt shy away from this course if political philosophy interests you, but I wouldn't take it as an elective, either.
No I would not.
I would if you are interested in philosophy otherwise I don't think I would take again.
Yes, if you need a political philosophy class, this definitely gives you the basics.

If you've never taken a philosophy course and want to try it out, I strongly recommend this course. The subject matter is accessible since we tend to center around American civic life and institutions. If you are not familiar with the American government system, it might be a little less intuitive; however, all perspectives add to our broader understanding of evaluation.
